elements.content: Pesticides are the primary defending strategy against major biological invaders and important for ensuring national food security. Intelligent nanopesticides with precise controlled release modes are currently an emerging area of interest in the field of green, safe, and sustainable pesticide formulation. In this study, β-cypermethrin (β-CYP) was loaded into ZIF-8 by the one-pot method, which successfully prepared a pH-responsive delivery nanoparticle (β-CYP/ZIF-8) to control termites. Results demonstrated that β-CYP/ZIF-8 had a mean diameter of 188 ± 2 nm and a loading capacity of approximately 21%. In vitro release experiments showed that β-CYP/ZIF-8 releases better in acidic than in neutral conditions due to the presence of intermediate acid-unstable imidazole organic compounds. The acidic microenvironment in which termites thrive can promote β-CYP release due to ZIF-8 decomposition, thus improving pesticide targeting and reducing toxic side effects. The bioactivity survey confirmed that β-CYP/ZIF-8 could control termites ( Shiraki) for a longer duration compared to commercial wettable powder (WP) and emulsifiable concentrate (EC). Moreover, an acute toxicity test showed an over 2- and 10-fold reduction in the acute toxicity of β-CYP/ZIF-8 to earthworms and zebrafish, respectively, compared to that of commercial WP and EC. Finally, the cytotoxicity assay of β-CYP/ZIF-8 showed higher safety to human hepatocyte LO2 cells. Overall, these β-CYP/ZIF-8 nanoparticles, prepared using the one-pot method, have great application potential in sustainable pest management and protection of the ecological environment.

management and protection of the ecological environment.

elements.content: Termites are ancient social insects that feed on fibrous materials. At present, more than 2800 termite species have been recorded. Termites, classified as one of the world’s five major pests by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO), are characterized by their strong survival ability, hidden nests, and long life span, cause a wide range of damage to properties, and threaten human life. In the United States, economic losses due to termite hazards exceed 3 billion dollars per year. As insects with relatively advanced evolution, termites cause irreversible harm to buildings, gardens, trees, water conservancy projects, transportation facilities, and telecommunication equipment. Termite damage is mainly reflected in the following aspects: (1) eating a variety of field crops, trees, and fruit trees, as well as flower seedlings, resulting in reduced or even no yield; (2) damaging buildings, eventually resulting in the sudden collapse of buildings, endangering the safety of human life and property; and (3) the damage of termites to soil dikes is the most critical in water conservancy projects. During the rainy season, the bearing capacity of the dam is greatly weakened by the erosion caused by termites, which can easily cause dike breaches, leading to huge disasters.

elements.content: β-Cypermethrin (β-CYP), a cyclopropane ester pesticide containing phenoxyalkyl, is used as a pyrethroid insecticide in China. It has a broad-spectrum insecticidal effect and high efficacy, which plays an important role in the pest control of vegetables, cotton, fruit trees, and other crops. In recent years, the damage caused by termites has become increasingly severe, and β-CYP has been used as a pyrethroid insecticide. However, studies have shown that β-CYP is highly toxic to some non-target organisms, especially fish, and irritates the human skin. Therefore, the scientific, effective, and safe use of β-CYP has always been the focus of research in the field of pesticides and environmental protection.

elements.content: An environmentally safe carrier can not only improve the efficiency of pesticide use but also greatly improve its safety, both for the environment and for the human body. Nanoparticles based on metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have become one of the most promising classes of drug delivery vehicles owing to their high capacity, tunable release, and the potential to simultaneously transport several different payloads to achieve synergistic therapeutic effects. ZIF-8 is a zeolitic imidazolate framework built from Zn2+ and 2-methylimidazolate, a typical material in this series. In addition to the general advantages of this type of material, it is unstable under acidic conditions; a large amount of drug is released by disintegration under such conditions but less so in a neutral environment, providing the possibility for its application in the field of acid-responsive drug delivery. At present, the research work on ZIF-8 mainly focuses on the selective adsorption catalysis of gas and the loading of anticancer drugs. There are few reports on the loading of insecticides.

elements.content: In this study, MOFs (ZIF-8) were loaded with β-CYP by the one-pot method (A) to constitute a pH-responsive pesticide delivery nanoparticle (β-CYP/ZIF-8), preventing premature losses in the environment and ensuring β-CYP being specifically released in the acid environment that accompanies termite infestation (B). While protecting the environment and improving biosecurity, termites can be controlled effectively and in environmentally friendly ways. The prepared β-CYP/ZIF-8 nanoparticles were characterized via scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), zeta potential analysis, nitrogen adsorption, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). In addition, the pesticide loading, release properties, release mechanism, insecticidal activities, acute toxicity to non-target organisms, and cytotoxicity of β-CYP/ZIF-8 nanoparticles were also evaluated. This work provides a promising approach to promote the development of green, safe, and sustainable intelligent-response pesticides, which can reduce the environmental impact of pesticides.

elements.content:
Formosan termites ( Shiraki) were collected from Yangzhou, Jiangsu Province, isolated, and raised for at least 1 week in a climate chamber (25 ± 1 °C and 85 ± 5% RH).

Synthesis of Nanoscale ZIF-8 and β-CYP/ZIF-8

For the typical preparation of β-CYP/ZIF-8, 0.78 g of β-CYP was dissolved in 15 mL of methanol to prepare the stock solutions; 0.56 g of Zn (NO3)2·6H2O was dissolved in 15 mL of methanol, and 15 mL of stock solutions was added under ultrasound at room temperature. After 5 min, 15 mL of methanol containing 0.62 g of 2-mim was added dropwise into the above solutions, and ultrasound was continued for 10 min. Samples were then incubated at 20 °C for 12 h. The obtained precipitates were centrifuged, washed with methanol more than three times to completely remove the unreacted reactants, and dried overnight in vacuum at 65 °C. ZIF-8 was similarly synthesized for comparison without using 15 mL of stock solutions containing β-CYP.
elements.clean_text:
Insect Samples
Formosan termites
( Shiraki) were
collected from Yangzhou, Jiangsu Province, isolated, and raised for
at least 1 week in a climate chamber (25 ± 1 °C and 85 ±
5% RH).
Synthesis of Nanoscale ZIF-8 and β-CYP/ZIF-8
For the typical preparation of β-CYP/ZIF-8, 0.78 g of β-CYP was dissolved in 15 mL of methanol
to prepare the stock solutions; 0.56 g of Zn (NO3)2·6H2O was dissolved in 15 mL of methanol,
and 15 mL of stock solutions was added under ultrasound at room temperature.
After 5 min, 15 mL of methanol containing 0.62 g of 2-mim was added
dropwise into the above solutions, and ultrasound was continued for
10 min. Samples were then incubated at 20 °C for 12 h. The obtained
precipitates were centrifuged, washed with methanol more than three
times to completely remove the unreacted reactants, and dried overnight
in vacuum at 65 °C. ZIF-8 was similarly synthesized for comparison
without using 15 mL of stock solutions containing β-CYP.

elements.content: The morphologies of ZIF-8 and β-CYP/ZIF-8 were determined by SEM using an S-4800II electron microscope and TEM on a Tecnai 12 electron microscope. The average particle size and zeta potentials were measured using a Zetasizer Nano ZS90 instrument by dynamic light scattering (DLS). The microstructures of ZIF-8 and β-CYP/ZIF-8 were measured by N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument. Infrared spectra were recorded using a Bruker FT-IR spectrometer using KBr pellets, scanned from 4000 to 400 cm–1. The crystallinity of ZIF-8 and β-CYP/ZIF-8 was investigated using D8 ADVANCE for XRD analysis at a rate of 2° min–1 in a scanning range of 5–50°. TGA measurements were performed using a Mettler-Toledo TGA 851e apparatus from 25 to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 in an N2 atmosphere. The amount of β-CYP loaded in ZIF-8 was also determined by high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) at 220 nm, which was carried out in an Agilent SB-C18 column (25 mm × 4.6 mm × 5 μm) using a mobile phase consisting of methanol: water (80:20, v/v) pumped at a flow rate of 1 mL min–1. The interaction mechanism between ZIF-8 and β-CYP was determined using a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha X-ray photoelectron spectrometer.

elements.content: A typical release system was prepared by suspending 100 mg of β-CYP/ZIF-8 in 200 mL of methanol–water (80:20, v/v) buffer solution (pH 4.5, 6.0, and 7.4, respectively). The release system was maintained at room temperature (25 °C) with shaking (shaking frequency = 150 rpm). A 1 mL sample was withdrawn from the medium at different time intervals and subsequently supplemented with an equal volume of fresh buffer solution. HPLC was used to determine the release ratio of β-CYP/ZIF-8, which was calculated using the following equation cumulative release percentage = V e ∑ i = 0 n − 1 C i + V 0 C n M i × 100 % where V e (1 mL) represents the sample volume recorded at various time intervals, C n represents the β-CYP concentration (mg/mL) in the release medium at time n, V 0 (200 mL) represents the volume of the release solution, and M i represents the total amount of loaded β-CYP.

elements.content: Bioassays of termites were carried out according to a previously reported method, with slight modifications. β-CYP/ZIF-8 nanoparticles with a certain mass were uniformly dispersed in water by ultrasonication to form a relatively stable suspension. The β-CYP/ZIF-8 suspension, 8% β-CYP WP, and 4.5% β-CYP EC were divided into five concentrations (0.5, 1.0, 2.0, 4.0, and 8.0 mg a.i./L) using the equal ratio method. Then, 1 mL of the above solution was evenly dripped into a Petri dish (diameter of 90 mm) lined with a filter paper. A total of 20 worker ants were placed inside the beakers, and all treatments were repeated three times. The test was performed at (27 ± 1) °C and in the dark, keeping the filter paper moist. Deionized water was used as the control treatment, and a separate treatment group was set up to investigate the biological activity of the carrier ZIF-8 on termites. The death of ants was observed after 24 h of treatment. All test insects were removed on the third day, and 20 healthy worker ants were added again. The death rate was calculated after 24 h of observation according to the above method. Similarly, the mortality of worker ants after 24 h of treatment was investigated on the 7th and 14th days, respectively. Death was defined as the absence of a response from all body parts when the abdomen was lightly touched with a blunt instrument. The relevant calculation formulas are as follows termites mortality = number of dead ants total number of test ants × 100 % relative mortality = mortality of treatment group − mortality of the control group 1 − mortality of the control group × 100 %

elements.content: The acute toxicity test of earthworms was performed using the artificial soil method according to the OECD 207 standard method. The three formulations were mixed with 500 g of artificial soil at the set concentration, and an appropriate amount of distilled water was added to adjust the water content to 30%. The medicated artificial soil was placed in a 1 L beaker. Ten healthy earthworms with clear intestines were placed inside the beakers, which were sealed with a gauze. The beakers were then incubated in an artificial climate incubator (illumination intensity: 400–800 l×) at a temperature of 20 ± 1 °C and a humidity of 80–85%. Eight concentrations (25, 50, 100, 200, 400, 800, 1600, and 3200 mg a.i./kg) were set for each formulation, with three replicates for each concentration. A set of blank controls was also prepared. The death rate of earthworms on the 7th and 14th days after treatment was recorded. An earthworm was considered dead when it did not respond to mechanical stimulation. In the environmental safety evaluation test of the chemical pesticide, the evaluation standard of pesticide toxicity to earthworms was as follows: 50% lethal concentration (LC50) ≤ 0.1 mg/kg, 0.1 < LC50 ≤ 1.0 mg/kg, 1.0 < LC50 ≤ 10.0 mg/kg, and LC50 > 10.0 mg/kg, indicating extreme, high, medium, and low toxicity levels, respectively.

Acute Toxicity to Non-target Organisms
Acute Toxicity to Earthworms
The
acute toxicity test of earthworms was performed using the artificial
soil method according to the OECD 207 standard method. The three formulations were mixed with 500 g
of artificial soil at the set concentration, and an appropriate amount
of distilled water was added to adjust the water content to 30%. The
medicated artificial soil was placed in a 1 L beaker. Ten healthy
earthworms with clear intestines were placed inside the beakers, which
were sealed with a gauze. The beakers were then incubated in an artificial
climate incubator (illumination intensity: 400–800 l×)
at a temperature of 20 ± 1 °C and a humidity of 80–85%.
Eight concentrations (25, 50, 100, 200, 400, 800, 1600, and 3200 mg
a.i./kg) were set for each formulation, with three replicates for
each concentration. A set of blank controls was also prepared. The
death rate of earthworms on the 7th and 14th days after treatment
was recorded. An earthworm was considered dead when it did not respond
to mechanical stimulation. In the environmental safety evaluation
test of the chemical pesticide, the evaluation standard of pesticide
toxicity to earthworms was as follows: 50% lethal concentration (LC50) ≤ 0.1 mg/kg, 0.1 < LC50 ≤ 1.0
mg/kg, 1.0 < LC50 ≤ 10.0 mg/kg, and LC50 > 10.0 mg/kg, indicating extreme, high, medium, and low toxicity
levels, respectively.

elements.content: The acute toxicity test of zebrafish was performed using a static method according to the OECD 203 standard method. According to the relevant literature, nine experimental concentrations (3.125, 6.25, 12.5, 25, 50, 100, 200, 400, and 800 μg a.i./L) were set through the pre-experiment. Four liters of the above solution was added to each fish tank. In addition, a blank control group was set. Ten zebrafish were added to each fish tank, with three replicates per group. The death rate of zebrafish was observed at 24, 48, 72, and 96 h. Zebrafish were considered dead when not responding to mechanical stimulation. In the environmental safety evaluation test of the chemical pesticide, the evaluation standard of pesticide toxicity to zebrafish was as follows: 50% lethal concentration (LC50) ≤ 0.1 mg/L, 0.1 < LC50 ≤ 1.0 mg/L, 1.0 < LC50 ≤ 10.0 mg/L, and LC50 > 10.0 mg/L, indicating extreme, high, medium, and low toxicity levels, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Acute Toxicity to Zebrafish
The
acute toxicity test of zebrafish was performed using a static method
according to the OECD 203 standard method. According to the relevant literature, nine experimental concentrations
(3.125, 6.25, 12.5, 25, 50, 100, 200, 400, and 800 μg a.i./L)
were set through the pre-experiment. Four liters of the above solution
was added to each fish tank. In addition, a blank control group was
set. Ten zebrafish were added to each fish tank, with three replicates
per group. The death rate of zebrafish was observed at 24, 48, 72,
and 96 h. Zebrafish were considered dead when not responding to mechanical
stimulation. In the environmental safety evaluation test of the chemical
pesticide, the evaluation standard of pesticide toxicity to zebrafish
was as follows: 50% lethal concentration (LC50) ≤
0.1 mg/L, 0.1 < LC50 ≤ 1.0 mg/L, 1.0 < LC50 ≤ 10.0 mg/L, and LC50 > 10.0 mg/L,
indicating
extreme, high, medium, and low toxicity levels, respectively.

elements.content: Human hepatocyte LO2 cells were obtained from the Medical College of Yangzhou University, cultured in Dulbecco’s modified Eagle’s medium (DMEM; containing 10% fetal bovine serum and 1% chain penicillin), and placed in a constant humidity cell incubator with 5% CO2 at 37 °C. Cells were then digested with a 0.25% trypsin solution, and then, the experiment was performed when the fusion exceeded 80%.
elements.clean_text:
Cytotoxicity
Cell Culture
Human hepatocyte LO2
cells were obtained from the Medical College of Yangzhou University,
cultured in Dulbecco’s modified Eagle’s medium (DMEM;
containing 10% fetal bovine serum and 1% chain penicillin), and placed
in a constant humidity cell incubator with 5% CO2 at 37
°C. Cells were then digested with
a 0.25% trypsin solution, and then, the experiment was performed when
the fusion exceeded 80%.

elements.content: LO2 cells, inoculated in 96-well plates at a density of 5 × 104 per well, were treated with 12.5, 25, 50, 100, and 200 mg a.i./L β-CYP/ZIF-8, and three replicates were set for each group. WP and EC were mixed with cells at the same concentrations as mentioned above. Control (containing the LO2 cell, culture medium, without drug) and blank groups (only containing the culture medium) were also set. After 24 and 48 h, 10 μL of CCK-8 was added to each well, and the incubation was continued for 2 h in a constant-temperature incubator. The absorbance value of each well was measured at 450 nm via enzyme-linked immunoassay (ELISA). Cell survival and growth were evaluated by calculating cell viability using cell viability = O D treatment group − O D blank group O D control group − O D blank group × 100 %

elements.content: Apoptosis detection was performed using annexin V-FITC/PI double staining. Logarithmic phase cells with good growth status were inoculated in 6-well plates at a density of 1 × 105 per well and divided into treatment and control groups. After 24 h, 50 mg a.i./L β-CYP/ZIF-8 and the commercially available WP and EC were added to the treatment groups, respectively. Equal amounts of the cell culture medium were added to the control group, and three replicates were set up for each group. Then, cells were cultured for 24 h, collected after trypsin digestion for 3 min, and centrifuged (800 rpm) for 5 min. The supernatant was discarded, and cells were washed twice with phosphate-buffered saline. Cells were resuspended in 100 μL of binding buffer. Cells were mixed with the FITC/PI fluorescent solution and incubated in an ice bath protected from light for 15 min. Finally, 400 μL of binding buffer was added and mixed evenly. Flow cytometry was used to determine the cell apoptosis rate.
elements.clean_text:
Cell Apoptosis Assay
Apoptosis
detection was performed using annexin V-FITC/PI double staining. Logarithmic phase cells with good growth status
were inoculated in 6-well plates at a density of 1 × 105 per well and divided into treatment and control groups. After 24
h, 50 mg a.i./L β-CYP/ZIF-8 and the commercially available WP
and EC were added to the treatment groups, respectively. Equal amounts
of the cell culture medium were added to the control group, and three
replicates were set up for each group. Then, cells were cultured for
24 h, collected after trypsin digestion for 3 min, and centrifuged
(800 rpm) for 5 min. The supernatant was discarded, and cells were
washed twice with phosphate-buffered saline. Cells were resuspended
in 100 μL of binding buffer. Cells were mixed with the FITC/PI
fluorescent solution and incubated in an ice bath protected from light
for 15 min. Finally, 400 μL of binding buffer was added and
mixed evenly. Flow cytometry was used to determine the cell apoptosis
rate.

elements.content: Herein, β-CYP was successfully loaded into the pores of ZIF-8 by a one-pot method to form β-CYP/ZIF-8. SEM and TEM characterizations (A) were carried out for ZIF-8 and β-CYP/ZIF-8. SEM images revealed that ZIF-8 nanoparticles exhibited a regular rhombic dodecahedron structure, but the edges of β-CYP/ZIF-8 became blurred and tended to be spherical. This morphological change was also demonstrated by TEM, which showed that the loading of β-CYP might have slightly affected the structural morphology of ZIF-8. Energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) showed that the Cl, N, Zn, O, and C elements were visible in the nanoparticles (B). The uniform distribution of Zn elements indicates the successful synthesis of the ZIF-8 framework. The Cl and O elements belonging to β-CYP were uniformly distributed in ZIF-8, indicating the presence of β-CYP in ZIF-8 nanoparticles. The particle size and distribution range for all the studied samples were further determined by DLS. As shown in C, the mean particle size of β-CYP/ZIF-8 was larger than that of ZIF-8 (from 162 ± 1 to 188 ± 2 nm), consistent with SEM and TEM results. In D, the zeta potentials of β-CYP, ZIF-8, and β-CYP/ZIF-8 were −37.9 ± 3.0, 28.4 ± 3.1, and 13.9 ± 1.1, respectively. Compared with that of ZIF-8, the decrease in the β-CYP/ZIF-8 potential demonstrates that β-CYP and ZIF-8 were successfully combined.

Results and Discussion
Synthesis and Characterization
Herein,
β-CYP was successfully loaded into the pores of ZIF-8 by a one-pot
method to form β-CYP/ZIF-8. SEM and TEM characterizations (A) were carried out
for ZIF-8 and β-CYP/ZIF-8. SEM images revealed that ZIF-8 nanoparticles
exhibited a regular rhombic dodecahedron structure, but the edges of β-CYP/ZIF-8 became blurred and tended
to be spherical. This morphological change was also demonstrated by
TEM, which showed that the loading of β-CYP might have slightly
affected the structural morphology of ZIF-8. Energy-dispersive spectroscopy
(EDS) showed that the Cl, N, Zn, O, and C elements were visible in
the nanoparticles (B). The uniform distribution of Zn elements indicates the
successful synthesis of the ZIF-8 framework. The Cl and O elements belonging to β-CYP were uniformly distributed
in ZIF-8, indicating the presence of β-CYP in ZIF-8 nanoparticles.
The particle size and distribution range for all the studied samples
were further determined by DLS. As shown in C, the mean particle size of β-CYP/ZIF-8
was larger than that of ZIF-8 (from 162 ± 1 to 188 ± 2 nm),
consistent with SEM and TEM results. In D, the zeta potentials of β-CYP, ZIF-8,
and β-CYP/ZIF-8 were −37.9 ± 3.0, 28.4 ± 3.1,
and 13.9 ± 1.1, respectively. Compared with that of ZIF-8, the
decrease in the β-CYP/ZIF-8 potential demonstrates that β-CYP
and ZIF-8 were successfully combined.

elements.content: Nitrogen adsorption–desorption experiments are commonly used to analyze the microstructures of inorganic porous materials. The specific surface areas of the prepared ZIF-8 and β-CYP/ZIF-8 were determined using this method at 77 K. As shown in E and , the frameworks of ZIF-8 and β-CYP/ZIF-8 both exhibit reversible type I isotherms and have steep N2 absorption in the low-pressure zone (P/P 0 < 0.05), which indicates the microporosity of ZIF-8. The surface area and total pore volume of the prepared ZIF-8 were 1153.15 m2/g and 0.53 cm3/g, respectively, which agree with the results obtained in the study by Meng et al. The surface area and total pore volume decreased markedly to 913.88 m2/g and 0.41 cm3/g after β-CYP loading, respectively. Meanwhile, the pore size decreased from 1.98 to 1.49, fully demonstrating the successful loading of β-CYP into β-CYP/ZIF-8.

elements.content: The synthesis of ZIF-8 and β-CYP/ZIF-8 was confirmed via FT-IR analysis (F). In the spectrum of ZIF-8, the absorption bands at 3138 and 2925 cm–1 correspond to the aromatic and aliphatic C–H stretching vibrations of the imidazole ring, respectively. The absorption peak at 1584 cm–1 was due to the stretching vibration of CN in the imidazole ring, while the band at 420 cm–1 is related to the stretching of Zn–N. Meanwhile, the FT-IR spectrum of β-CYP/ZIF-8 is a superposition of β-CYP and ZIF-8 nanoparticles. In addition to the absorption bands of ZIF-8, the characteristic band at 2955 cm–1 corresponds to the −CH3 vibrations of β-CYP. The peaks appeared at 1737 and 422 cm–1 are attributed to the CO and C–Cl vibrations, respectively, both of which can be observed in β-CYP.
elements.clean_text:
The synthesis of ZIF-8 and β-CYP/ZIF-8 was confirmed
via
FT-IR analysis (F). In the spectrum of ZIF-8, the absorption bands at 3138 and 2925
cm–1 correspond to the aromatic and aliphatic C–H
stretching vibrations of the imidazole ring, respectively. The absorption peak at 1584 cm–1 was due to the stretching vibration of CN in the imidazole
ring, while the band at 420 cm–1 is related to the
stretching of Zn–N. Meanwhile,
the FT-IR spectrum of β-CYP/ZIF-8 is a superposition of β-CYP
and ZIF-8 nanoparticles. In addition to the absorption bands of ZIF-8,
the characteristic band at 2955 cm–1 corresponds
to the −CH3 vibrations of β-CYP. The peaks
appeared at 1737 and 422 cm–1 are attributed to
the CO and C–Cl vibrations, respectively, both of which
can be observed in β-CYP.

elements.content: The XRD characterization results of ZIF-8, β-CYP/ZIF-8, and β-CYP are shown in G. The XRD pattern revealed that seven diffraction peaks at 7.31, 10.31, 12.71, 14.71, 16.41, 18.01, and 26.71 could be indexed to the (011), (002), (112), (022), (013), (222), and (134) planes, respectively. The typical diffraction peaks and the positions of the peaks were consistent with those reported in the literature, confirming that the sample was ZIF-8. β-CYP/ZIF-8 showed characteristic peaks consistent with those of ZIF-8, indicating that the loading process had no effect on the crystalline structure of ZIF-8, and its crystal structure remained intact. Meanwhile, the decrease in intensity values for β-CYP/ZIF-8 indicates that the β-CYP molecules were indeed encapsulated in the ZIF-8 pores.
elements.clean_text:
The XRD characterization results
of ZIF-8, β-CYP/ZIF-8, and
β-CYP are shown in G. The XRD pattern revealed that seven diffraction
peaks at 7.31, 10.31, 12.71, 14.71, 16.41, 18.01, and 26.71 could
be indexed to the (011), (002), (112), (022), (013), (222), and (134)
planes, respectively. The typical diffraction peaks and the positions
of the peaks were consistent with those reported in the literature, confirming that the sample was ZIF-8. β-CYP/ZIF-8
showed characteristic peaks consistent with those of ZIF-8, indicating
that the loading process had no effect on the crystalline structure
of ZIF-8, and its crystal structure remained intact. Meanwhile, the
decrease in intensity values for β-CYP/ZIF-8 indicates that
the β-CYP molecules were indeed encapsulated in the ZIF-8 pores.

elements.content: For further characterization, TGA was performed, and the resulting curves are shown in H. The results show a rapid weight loss step of 100% from 200 to 300 °C, indicating that the structures of β-CYP were unstable at temperatures above 200 °C. The curve for ZIF-8 displayed features similar to those previously reported. The first weight loss step before 200 °C corresponds to the removal of solvent molecules from ZIF-8. A plateau appeared from 200 to 500 °C, indicating that the structure of ZIF-8 was stable. At approximately 600 °C, the mass of organic ligands decreased sharply by approximately 20% due to the decomposition and carbonization of organic ligands. The weight loss above 600 °C is caused by the collapse of the ZIF-8 structure. β-CYP/ZIF-8 showed an excess weight loss from 200 to 600 °C due to the slow decomposition of β-CYP. The excess weight loss was approximately 22%. This observation indicated that ZIF-8 could improve the thermal stability of β-CYP.

elements.content:
Therefore, it is clear that ZIF-8 was successfully synthesized, and β-CYP was incorporated into the ZIF-8 framework by the above characterization.

Interaction Mechanism between β-CYP and ZIF-8

The XPS survey spectrum of β-CYP/ZIF-8 (A) showed the characteristic elemental peak of ZIF-8 in addition to the Cl 2p peak at 201.1 eV, indicating that ZIF-8 was successfully loaded with β-CYP. To further investigate the interaction mechanism between β-CYP and ZIF-8 nanoparticles, the samples were characterized via Zn 2p and O 1s analysis at a high resolution. As shown in B, the Zn 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 peaks of ZIF-8 were observed at 1021.6 and 1044.7 eV, respectively. However, after β-CYP loading, these two peaks were shifted, indicating the possibility of an interaction force between β-CYP and Zn. Furthermore, the O 1s XPS spectrum for β-CYP showed two peaks at 533.2 eV (C–O) and 531.8 eV (CO), and β-CYP/ZIF-8 showed a Zn–O peak at 531.6 eV accompanied by two peaks corresponding to C–O and CO, which were shifted compared to their positions in the spectrum of β-CYP. These observations could be attributed to the formation of coordination bonds between some of the O in β-CYP and Zn in ZIF-8 nanoparticles.

Interaction Mechanism between β-CYP
and ZIF-8
The XPS survey spectrum of β-CYP/ZIF-8 (A) showed the characteristic
elemental peak of ZIF-8 in addition to the Cl 2p peak at 201.1 eV,
indicating that ZIF-8 was successfully loaded with β-CYP. To
further investigate the interaction mechanism between β-CYP
and ZIF-8 nanoparticles, the samples were characterized via Zn 2p
and O 1s analysis at a high resolution. As shown in B, the Zn 2p3/2 and
2p1/2 peaks of ZIF-8 were observed at 1021.6 and 1044.7
eV, respectively. However, after β-CYP loading, these two peaks
were shifted, indicating the possibility of an interaction force between
β-CYP and Zn. Furthermore, the O 1s XPS spectrum for β-CYP
showed two peaks at 533.2 eV (C–O) and 531.8 eV (CO),
and β-CYP/ZIF-8 showed a Zn–O peak at 531.6 eV accompanied
by two peaks corresponding to C–O and CO, which were
shifted compared to their positions in the spectrum of β-CYP.
These observations could be attributed to the formation of coordination
bonds between some of the O in β-CYP and Zn in ZIF-8 nanoparticles.

elements.content: The loading efficiency of β-CYP in the β-CYP/ZIF-8 nanoparticles was determined by HPLC. The calculated result was 21.0 ± 0.5%, consistent with TGA results. shows the release of β-CYP from β-CYP/ZIF-8 nanoparticles at different pH values (4.5, 6.0, and 7.4) at room temperature. After 5 days of treatment, the cumulative release rates of β-CYP/ZIF-8 nanoparticles reached 66.95 ± 2.36 and 98.20 ± 3.61% at pH 6.0 and 4.5, respectively, largely exceeding those under neutral conditions (pH 7.4). This tendency was due to acidic conditions that can protonate organic ligands, leading to the cleavage of the Zn+–imidazolium ion coordination bond, thereby decomposing the ZIF-8 skeleton to release the drug.
elements.clean_text:
Pesticide Loading Efficiency and Controlled
Release Kinetics
The loading efficiency of β-CYP in
the β-CYP/ZIF-8 nanoparticles was determined by HPLC. The calculated result was 21.0 ± 0.5%,
consistent with TGA results.  shows the release of β-CYP from β-CYP/ZIF-8
nanoparticles at different pH values (4.5, 6.0, and 7.4) at room temperature.
After 5 days of treatment, the cumulative release rates of β-CYP/ZIF-8
nanoparticles reached 66.95 ± 2.36 and 98.20 ± 3.61% at
pH 6.0 and 4.5, respectively, largely exceeding those under neutral
conditions (pH 7.4). This tendency was due to acidic conditions that
can protonate organic ligands, leading to the cleavage of the Zn+–imidazolium ion coordination bond, thereby decomposing
the ZIF-8 skeleton to release the drug.

elements.content: Fitting results of the kinetic model of the release curve at different pH. Results are presented as means ± standard deviation (n = 3).

elements.content: The mechanism of β-CYP release from β-CYP/ZIF-8 nanoparticles was further investigated by fitting four different kinetic models. The correlation coefficients of fitted equations () showed that the data of β-CYP at pH 6.0 and 7.4 were better fitted with the first-order model. The controlled release kinetics of β-CYP/ZIF-8 nanoparticles at pH 4.5 was well predicted using the Ritger–Peppas model (n = 0.45). Based on the above analysis, the release of β-CYP from β-CYP/ZIF-8 nanoparticles was mainly controlled by non-Fickian diffusion (0.43 < n < 0.85).

elements.content: To explore the application potential of β-CYP/ZIF-8 in the control of termites ( Shiraki), the insecticidal activity of the prepared β-CYP/ZIF-8 was compared with that of commercial WP and EC. As shown in A, the mortality rates of the three β-CYP formulations for termites were dose-dependent. Although the mortality of termites treated with β-CYP/ZIF-8 was lower than that of the other two commercial formulations after day 1, there was no significant difference among the above three. As time went on, the mortality rates of termites treated with β-CYP/ZIF-8 from 3 to 14 days after spraying were higher than those of commercial WP and EC at the same concentration. Even after 14 days, the mortality rate for the high concentration of β-CYP/ZIF-8 treatment (8 mg a.i./L) was still over 70%, unlike that of commercial WP and EC, which decreased to 41.7 and 45.0%, respectively. The median lethal concentration (LC50) values also showed that the toxicity of β-CYP/ZIF-8 for termites began to be higher than that of the other two commercial formulations after 3 days (). At 14 days, the LC50 of β-CYP/ZIF-8 treatment was more than 2 times higher than that of the two commercial formulations. Meanwhile, the results of the bioactivity assay corresponding to the blank carrier ZIF-8 against termites (B) showed that ZIF-8 had almost no killing effect on the termites, indicating that the lethal effect of β-CYP/ZIF-8 on the termites was primarily due to the loaded active ingredient, β-CYP. The insecticidal activity differences between β-CYP/ZIF-8 and the two commercial formulations can be explained as follows: in the early stage, β-CYP/ZIF-8 had just started contact with termites, and the amount of drug released was low, which resulted in low insecticidal activity. However, as time went on, the continuous activity of the termites increased the acidity of the environment, leading to the disintegration of the ZIF-8 framework and the consequent release of the large amounts of the loaded pesticide on demand, hence the high insecticidal activity was observed later. Therefore, this pH-responsive pesticide-loaded MOF provides an intelligent strategy for controlling termites in modern agriculture.

The pesticides used to control termites easily form residues in the soil, causing pollution since they are mainly active on land. The earthworm, a soil macroinvertebrate, is a typical model organism for ecotoxicological diagnostic studies of soil contamination. Therefore, the acute toxicity of earthworms is an important aspect of pesticide control and safety. According to A, the LC50 values of β-CYP/ZIF-8, WP, and EC were 1110.35, 568.12, and 509.83 mg a.i./kg at 7 days, respectively. At 14 days, their LC50 values were 943.63, 465.45, and 410.83 mg a.i./kg. Results showed that the three formulations had low toxicity, and the LC50 of β-CYP/ZIF-8 to earthworms was the highest, indicating that its acute toxicity to earthworms was the lowest. This is due to the use of Zn, a trace metal element contained in the soil, as a dispersion system in β-CYP/ZIF-8 instead of organic solvents. Meanwhile, owing to the neutral nature of artificial soil (pH = 7 ± 0.5), the ZIF-8 framework decomposed slowly. Thus, the drug could not be completely released, which is the reason for the low toxicity. In contrast, the commercially available WP and EC incorporate a large number of unknown types of organic solvents and surfactants, potentially leading to higher toxicity to earthworms.
elements.clean_text:
Acute Toxicity to Non-target Organisms
Acute Toxicity to Earthworms
The
pesticides used to control termites easily form residues in the soil,
causing pollution since they are mainly active on land. The earthworm,
a soil macroinvertebrate, is a typical model organism for ecotoxicological
diagnostic studies of soil contamination. Therefore, the acute toxicity of earthworms is an important aspect
of pesticide control and safety. According to A, the LC50 values of β-CYP/ZIF-8,
WP, and EC were 1110.35, 568.12, and 509.83 mg a.i./kg at 7 days,
respectively. At 14 days, their LC50 values were 943.63,
465.45, and 410.83 mg a.i./kg. Results showed that the three formulations
had low toxicity, and the LC50 of β-CYP/ZIF-8 to
earthworms was the highest, indicating that its acute toxicity to
earthworms was the lowest. This is due to the use of Zn, a trace metal
element contained in the soil, as a dispersion system in β-CYP/ZIF-8
instead of organic solvents. Meanwhile, owing to the neutral nature
of artificial soil (pH = 7 ± 0.5), the ZIF-8 framework decomposed
slowly. Thus, the drug could not be completely released, which is
the reason for the low toxicity. In contrast, the commercially available
WP and EC incorporate a large number of unknown types of organic solvents
and surfactants, potentially leading to higher toxicity to earthworms.

elements.content: Considering that β-CYP is reportedly highly toxic to aquatic organisms, it is of great significance to select zebrafish as a well-established model organism for toxicity assessment in vivo and to evaluate the biosafety of β-CYP/ZIF-8. As shown in B, the mortality of each treatment group increased with concentration, and LC50 increased with time. In addition, the toxicity of β-CYP/ZIF-8 to zebrafish was significantly lower than that of WP and EC at different times. Considering that the LC50 value of β-CYP/ZIF-8 was over 10-fold higher than those of WP and EC at 96 h, it implied that β-CYP/ZIF-8 was more environmentally friendly. Compared with commercial formulations (WP and EC), β-CYP was wrapped in ZIF-8 and had no direct contact with zebrafish. Meanwhile, the ZIF-8 frame is difficult to disintegrate under the condition of water pH, and β-CYP is released less, so the β-CYP concentration around zebrafish is lower.
elements.clean_text:
Acute Toxicity to Zebrafish
Considering
that β-CYP is reportedly highly toxic to aquatic organisms,
it is of great significance to select zebrafish as a well-established
model organism for toxicity assessment in vivo and to evaluate the
biosafety of β-CYP/ZIF-8. As shown
in B, the mortality
of each treatment group increased with concentration, and LC50 increased with time. In addition, the toxicity of β-CYP/ZIF-8
to zebrafish was significantly lower than that of WP and EC at different
times. Considering that the LC50 value of β-CYP/ZIF-8
was over 10-fold higher than those of WP and EC at 96 h, it implied
that β-CYP/ZIF-8 was more environmentally friendly. Compared
with commercial formulations (WP and EC), β-CYP was wrapped
in ZIF-8 and had no direct contact with zebrafish. Meanwhile, the
ZIF-8 frame is difficult to disintegrate under the condition of water
pH, and β-CYP is released less, so the β-CYP concentration
around zebrafish is lower.

elements.content:
Therefore, these experiments indicate that the loading of β-CYP in the ZIF-8 carrier significantly reduces β-CYP toxicity to non-target organisms, showing good application prospects.

CytotoxicityCell Viability Assay

To investigate the safety of β-CYP/ZIF-8 in the human body, LO2 cells and human liver cells were utilized to estimate the toxicity via a CCK-8 assay at five concentrations. As shown in A, cell viability gradually decreased as the material concentration increased at 24 or 48 h. At 24 h, the effect of the low concentration β-CYP/ZIF-8 treatment (e.g., 12.5 mg/L) was not significantly different from that of the control treatment, indicating little or no effect on the LO2 cells. However, the cell survival rate of β-CYP/ZIF-8 was always higher than that of WP and EC at all doses, and there was a significant difference. After 48 h, the survival rate of cells treated with 200 mg a.i./L WP and EC was lower than 50% while that of the β-CYP/ZIF-8 treatment group was still higher than 80%, reaching 80.3%. Commercial WP and EC presented high cytotoxicity due to direct contact with cells, and β-CYP/ZIF-8 reduced toxicity by encapsulating β-CYP and reducing contact with the cells. The results verified that β-CYP/ZIF-8 had significant biocompatibility as a pesticide drug carrier.

elements.content: The effect of β-CYP/ZIF-8 on the apoptosis of LO2 cells was detected using flow cytometry. B shows that β-CYP/ZIF-8 had less effect on the apoptosis of LO2 cells compared with that of WP and EC. We analyzed cell apoptosis and found that the total apoptosis rate of β-CYP/ZIF-8 (3.19%) was not significantly different from that of the control (2.90%) and was significantly lower than that of WP (7.16%) and EC (15.81%). The apoptosis effect of LO2 cells induced by three β-CYP formulations was further analyzed, showing that late apoptosis was more obvious than early apoptosis, except for EC. Therefore, β-CYP/ZIF-8 is relatively safe for LO2 cells compared to WP and EC. This further indicates that β-CYP/ZIF-8 is safe in the human body.

Cell Apoptosis Assay
The effect
of β-CYP/ZIF-8 on the apoptosis of LO2 cells was detected using
flow cytometry. B shows that β-CYP/ZIF-8 had less effect on the apoptosis of
LO2 cells compared with that of WP and EC. We analyzed cell apoptosis
and found that the total apoptosis rate of β-CYP/ZIF-8 (3.19%)
was not significantly different from that of the control (2.90%) and
was significantly lower than that of WP (7.16%) and EC (15.81%). The
apoptosis effect of LO2 cells induced by three β-CYP formulations
was further analyzed, showing that late apoptosis was more obvious
than early apoptosis, except for EC. Therefore, β-CYP/ZIF-8
is relatively safe for LO2 cells compared to WP and EC. This further
indicates that β-CYP/ZIF-8 is safe in the human body.

elements.content: In this work, an environmentally friendly and pH-responsive carrier, ZIF-8, was constructed with β-CYP loading to control termites. Through the characterization of N2 adsorption–desorption, FT-IR, XRD, and TGA, we showed that β-CYP/ZIF-8 nanoparticles with a mean diameter of 188 ± 2 nm and a loading capacity of approximately 21% were successfully prepared. The bioassay of termites demonstrated that β-CYP/ZIF-8 had satisfactory toxicity and a longer insecticidal duration than commercial WP and EC. The biosafety experiment showed that ZIF-8 could effectively reduce the acute toxicity of β-CYP to non-target organisms (earthworms and zebrafish) compared with that of commercial WP and EC. Meanwhile, β-CYP/ZIF-8 exhibited lower cytotoxicity, indicating better biocompatibility and human safety. Therefore, the potential of ZIF-8 to deliver β-CYP in a pH-triggered manner to control termites and reduce environmental impact was successfully demonstrated. These findings can be applied to promote green and sustainable development based on intelligent nanopesticide applications.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions
In this work, an environmentally
friendly and pH-responsive carrier,
ZIF-8, was constructed with β-CYP loading to control termites.
Through the characterization of N2 adsorption–desorption,
FT-IR, XRD, and TGA, we showed that β-CYP/ZIF-8 nanoparticles
with a mean diameter of 188 ± 2 nm and a loading capacity of
approximately 21% were successfully prepared. The bioassay of termites
demonstrated that β-CYP/ZIF-8 had satisfactory toxicity and
a longer insecticidal duration than commercial WP and EC. The biosafety
experiment showed that ZIF-8 could effectively reduce the acute toxicity
of β-CYP to non-target organisms (earthworms and zebrafish)
compared with that of commercial WP and EC. Meanwhile, β-CYP/ZIF-8
exhibited lower cytotoxicity, indicating better biocompatibility and
human safety. Therefore, the potential of ZIF-8 to deliver β-CYP
in a pH-triggered manner to control termites and reduce environmental
impact was successfully demonstrated. These findings can be applied
to promote green and sustainable development based on intelligent
nanopesticide applications.
